perturbation.original_text: it will notify the Sponsor promptly in writing of the full particulars of any material change, whether actual, anticipated or threatened, in any material fact stated or referred to in the Prospectus or which would result in an omission from the Prospectus to state a material fact necessary to make any statement contained therein not misleading in light of the circumstances in which it is made
perturbation.changed_text: it will notify the Sponsor when the Issuer deems it reasonably necessary regarding changes or omissions to a material fact stated or referred to in the Prospectus or which would result in an omission from the Prospectus to state a material fact necessary to make any statement contained therein not misleading in light of the circumstances in which it is made
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires prompt notification of any material change. The modified text changes the language to notify the sponsor only when the issuer deems it reasonably necessary. This contradicts the definition of 'material change' and 'misrepresentation' under the Securities Act (British Columbia), which mandates immediate disclosure regardless of the issuer's subjective assessment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Act (British Columbia) - definition of 'material change' and requirements for continuous disclosure

perturbation.original_text: The Issuer shall and does hereby indemnify and save the Indemnified Parties harmless from and against any liability, claim, demand or loss, excluding loss of profits, which the Indemnified Parties may suffer, whether pursuant to statute or otherwise, howsoever arising, in consequence of: (a) any statement or omission in the Prospectus, or otherwise made or omitted by the Issuer in connection with the Offering, being or being alleged to be a misrepresentation
perturbation.changed_text: The Issuer shall indemnify the Indemnified Parties from loss, except when it arises from misrepresentation that the Indemnified party should have been aware of. This applies to any statement or omission in the Prospectus, or otherwise made or omitted by the Issuer in connection with the Offering.
perturbation.explanation: By adding 'except when it arises from misrepresentation that the Indemnified party should have been aware of', the modified text weakens the indemnification clause. This alteration allows the Issuer to avoid indemnification if the Indemnified Parties (Sponsor) should have known about the misrepresentation, directly conflicting with the intention of full indemnity against misstatements in the Prospectus and creating uncertainty about the sponsor's liability under Securities Law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Law (British Columbia) - regarding due diligence requirements and liability for misrepresentation in prospectuses

perturbation.original_text: Sponsor will conduct an investigation of the organization, management, business and affairs of the Issuer sufficient, in its sole discretion, to enable it to determine whether or not it is able to sign the certificate of the Prospectus.
perturbation.changed_text: Sponsor will conduct a basic review of the Issuer's business to see whether or not it is able to sign the certificate of the Prospectus.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'investigation' was replaced by a 'basic review,' introducing ambiguity. The term investigation implies a more thorough analysis under securities law, while 'basic review' is less demanding. This diminishes the sponsor's obligation to conduct thorough due diligence, potentially resulting in liability.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Law (British Columbia) - due diligence requirements for sponsors of securities offerings
